SEARCH
Package com.dua3.utility.concurrent

Class AutoLock

java.lang.Object
com.dua3.utility.concurrent.AutoLock
All Implemented Interfaces:
AutoCloseable
public final class AutoLock extends Object implements AutoCloseable
The AutoLock class is a utility designed for safely managing locks using the auto-closeable pattern. It ensures that the lock is acquired when the object is created and automatically released when the object is closed.

This class is useful for managing critical sections where the lock's state should be reliably controlled without manual intervention to avoid issues such as deadlocks or forgotten unlocks.

The AutoLock class relies on the Lock interface for locking behavior, which should be provided during its creation.

Logging is performed during the creation and release of a lock, providing trace-level information about the lock's lifecycle and its associated name, if provided. This is helpful for debugging purposes and understanding the flow of lock usage.

To create an instance of AutoLock, use one of the static factory methods. The lock can be associated with an optional name for traceability or simply remain unnamed.

Upon successful object creation, the provided lock is acquired, and it remains locked until the close() method is called, either explicitly or implicitly (e.g., via a try-with-resources statement).

  • Method Details

    • of

      public static AutoLock of(Lock lock)
      Creates an AutoLock instance and acquires the specified lock immediately. The lock will remain acquired until the close() method is invoked (e.g., via a try-with-resources block or explicit manual call to close()).

      When using this method, the AutoLock instance is unnamed and trace logs will refer to it as "unnamed".

      Parameters:
      lock - the Lock instance to be managed by the created
      Returns:
      a new AutoLock instance that manages the specified lock.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if the provided lock is null.

    • of

      public static AutoLock of(Lock lock, String name)
      Creates an AutoLock instance and acquires the specified lock immediately. The lock will remain acquired until the close() method is invoked (e.g., via a try-with-resources block or explicit manual call to close()).

      The provided name is used for trace-level logging, aiding in identifying the lock instance and its lifecycle for debugging purposes.

      Parameters:
      lock - the Lock instance to be managed by this AutoLock. Must be non-null and provide thread-safe locking and unlocking behavior.
      name - a descriptive name for the lock, used for logging purposes. Must be non-null and convertible to a string representation.
      Returns:
      an AutoLock instance managing the specified Lock with the provided name for traceability.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if the provided lock or name is null.

    • of

      public static AutoLock of(Lock lock, Supplier<String> name)
      Creates an AutoLock instance for the specified Lock and a name supplier. The returned AutoLock ensures that the provided lock is acquired upon creation and will be released when the AutoLock is closed.
      Parameters:
      lock - the Lock instance to be managed, must not be null.
      name - a Supplier<String> providing a name for the lock, used for logging and traceability.
      Returns:
      an AutoLock instance managing the specified lock with the associated name.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if either lock or name is null.

    • close

      public void close()
      Releases the lock managed by this AutoLock instance.

      This method is invoked automatically when the AutoLock instance is used within a try-with-resources block, or it can be called manually to release the lock. Trace-level logging is performed to record the lock release operation, including the name of the lock (if provided) and its identity hash code for debugging purposes.

      Once this method is called, the lock is no longer held by the calling thread. It is essential to ensure that this method is invoked to prevent potential deadlocks or resource leaks by retaining the lock unnecessarily.

      Specified by:
      close in interface AutoCloseable
